title: Modeling the Pnear Distribution
text: common task molecular modeling predict conformation folded state given molecular system. example, Rosetta ab initio, protein-protein-interface docking protocols. turn simulation prediction requires predicting relative free energy folded state relative reference. Rosetta score function can score individual conformations, doesn’t capture free energy state. Typically, researcher run series trajectories generate score vs. RMSD plot look “folding funnel” e.g. lower energies conformations closer target folded state. , RMSD root-mean squared deviation measuring euclidean distance pairs atom defined application (example just backbone sequence design interface atoms docking).

title: Modeling the Pnear Distribution
text: quantify quality folding funnel, recently, interest using Pnear score, defined (RMSD[], score[]) score RMSD score values conformation . parameter lambda measured Angstroms indicating breadth Gaussian used define “native-like-ness”. bigger value, permissive calculation structures deviate native. Typical values peptides range 1.5 2.0, proteins 2.0 perhaps 4.0. finally parameter k_BT measured energy units, determines large energy gap must order sequence said favour native state. default value, 0.62, correspond physiological temperature ref2015 scorefunction units kcal/mol.
code: Pnear = Sum_i[exp(-RMSD[i]^2/lambda^2)*exp(-score[i]/k_BT)] /         Sum_i[exp(-score[i]/k_BT)]

title: Modeling the Pnear Distribution
text: Thinking folded unfolded states two-state model RSMD reaction coordinate “collective variable”, energy gap can modeled sigmoidal Boltzmann distribution.  principled molecular dynamics monte carlo simulation maintains detailed balance, theory possible use thermodynamic integration quantify energy gap two states. However, often computationally feasible proteins moderate size protein design screening context many different molecules need evaluated given limited computational budget. , Instead, assume least locally around folded state, degrees freedom increase exponentially log RMSD defines linear reaction coordinate. simulate, trajectory points sigmoid log(RMSD) scale, Normally distributed error can generate synthetic score-vs-rmsd plots  nice thing parametric model generate score-vs-rmsd plots, allows us measure measure sensitivity Pnear differently shaped score-vs-rmsd plots. example can scann radius  Another question can use model investigate reproducible Pnear score?

title: Modeling the Pnear Distribution
text: case study, can look real score-vs-rmsd plots Antibody SnugDock scientific benchmark. evaluates SnugDock protocol 6 Antibody protein targets can use fit sigmoid model log(RMSD) using BayesPharma package, relies BRMS Stan Check model parameter fit estimated parameters: Excitingly, using leave-one-cross-validation, sigmoid model fits data well Visualize fit draws expected mean median quantile intvervals log(RMSD) scale: original RMSD scale:
code: ##  Family: gaussian  ##   Links: mu = identity; sigma = identity  ## Formula: response ~ sigmoid(ec50, hill, top, bottom, log_dose)  ##          ec50 ~ 0 + target ##          hill ~ 0 + target ##          top ~ 0 + target ##          bottom ~ 0 + target ##    Data: data (Number of observations: 3003)  ##   Draws: 4 chains, each with iter = 4000; warmup = 0; thin = 1; ##          total post-warmup draws = 16000 ##  ## Population-Level Effects:  ##                   Estimate Est.Error l-95% CI u-95% CI Rhat Bulk_ESS Tail_ESS ## ec50_target1ahw       1.70      0.11     1.44     1.87 1.00     7740     4513 ## ec50_target1jps       1.37      0.13     1.08     1.59 1.00     8874     6536 ## ec50_target1mlc       2.40      0.51     1.03     3.18 1.00     6044     4526 ## ec50_target1ztx       0.75      0.08     0.59     0.89 1.00    11214     8069 ## ec50_target2aep       1.11      0.28     0.58     1.52 1.00     7513     4998 ## ec50_target2jel       1.65      0.06     1.53     1.76 1.00    12330    10372 ## hill_target1ahw       1.69      0.43     0.89     2.59 1.00     6352     4182 ## hill_target1jps       1.50      0.36     0.89     2.28 1.00     7644     7306 ## hill_target1mlc       1.03      0.56     0.26     2.30 1.00     6129     6389 ## hill_target1ztx       2.72      0.55     1.77     3.90 1.00    13337    10781 ## hill_target2aep       1.99      0.66     0.71     3.35 1.00     5190     2210 ## hill_target2jel       3.20      0.59     2.12     4.46 1.00    14650     9647 ## top_target1ahw      -10.56      0.69   -11.58    -8.89 1.00     9198     5035 ## top_target1jps       -9.70      0.58   -10.61    -8.31 1.00    10498     7618 ## top_target1mlc       -1.31      5.88    -9.85    12.50 1.00    13063     9766 ## top_target1ztx      -17.44      0.28   -17.99   -16.89 1.00    20977    11208 ## top_target2aep      -16.29      0.81   -16.94   -15.41 1.00     6665     2411 ## top_target2jel      -11.10      0.33   -11.74   -10.44 1.00    21302    10870 ## bottom_target1ahw   -26.01      2.17   -31.42   -23.12 1.00     6545     3962 ## bottom_target1jps   -30.48      3.73   -39.69   -25.00 1.00     8033     6747 ## bottom_target1mlc   -18.44      4.27   -31.02   -14.76 1.00     5462     4307 ## bottom_target1ztx   -38.89      3.54   -46.93   -33.04 1.00    11450     8217 ## bottom_target2aep   -30.32      5.93   -43.93   -21.23 1.00    12557     8274 ## bottom_target2jel   -19.46      0.98   -21.61   -17.73 1.00    12812    10033 ##  ## Family Specific Parameters:  ##       Estimate Est.Error l-95% CI u-95% CI Rhat Bulk_ESS Tail_ESS ## sigma     5.74      0.07     5.60     5.89 1.00    20759    11726 ##  ## Draws were sampled using sample(hmc). For each parameter, Bulk_ESS ## and Tail_ESS are effective sample size measures, and Rhat is the potential ## scale reduction factor on split chains (at convergence, Rhat = 1). ##  ## Computed from 16000 by 3003 log-likelihood matrix ##  ##          Estimate   SE ## elpd_loo  -9521.0 39.0 ## p_loo        21.2  1.1 ## looic     19042.1 77.9 ## ------ ## Monte Carlo SE of elpd_loo is 0.0. ##  ## All Pareto k estimates are good (k < 0.5). ## See help('pareto-k-diagnostic') for details.

what: Compute the Pnear quality metric for RMSD funnel — Pnear
title: Compute the Pnear quality metric for RMSD funnel — Pnear
text: Pnear metric defined [(Bhardwaj, et al., Nature, 2016)](https://www.nature.com/articles/nature19791) measures "funnel-like" score-vs-rmsd plot . https://github.com/RosettaCommons/main/blob/master/tests/benchmark/util/quality_measures.py#L268

title: Compute the Pnear quality metric for RMSD funnel — Pnear
code: Pnear(score, rmsd, lambda = 1.5, kbt = 0.62, verbose = FALSE)

title: Compute the Pnear quality metric for RMSD funnel — Pnear
text: lambda Lambda value Angstroms indicating breadth Gaussian used define "native-like-ness".  bigger value, permissive calculation structures deviate native. Typical values peptides range 1.5 2.0, proteins 2.0 perhaps 4.0. kbt value k_B*T, energy units, determines large energy gap must order sequence said favour native state. default value, 0.62, correspond physiological temperature ref2015 scorefunction units kcal/mol. scores vector scores e.g. Rosetta energies e.g. Ref2015. rmsds root mean squared deviation values e.g. backbone atoms

title: Compute the Pnear quality metric for RMSD funnel — Pnear
text: Unlike Conway discrimination score, PNear calculation uses hard cutoffs.  advantageous repeated testing: scatter points RMSD plot changes slightly run run, PNear value change small amount, whereas metric dependent hard cutoffs change large amount low-energy point crosses RMSD threshold.

title: Compute the Pnear quality metric for RMSD funnel — Pnear
text: Vikram K. Mulligan (vmulligan\@flatironinstitute.org) adapted Rosetta

what: Add a log dose (in base 10) column to the input data.frame — calculate_log_dose
title: Add a log dose (in base 10) column to the input data.frame — calculate_log_dose
text: Given dose column data.frame given molar concentration    add new column log base-10 dose, `log_dose`, data.frame return .

title: Add a log dose (in base 10) column to the input data.frame — calculate_log_dose
code: calculate_log_dose(   data,   dose_col = 1,   molar_concentration = 1)

title: Add a log dose (in base 10) column to the input data.frame — calculate_log_dose
text: data data.frame containing column representing dose molar units. dose_col expression dose column input data.frame (default = dose). molar_concentration numeric units molar concentration (default = 1).

title: Add a log dose (in base 10) column to the input data.frame — calculate_log_dose
text: input data.frame additional `log_dose` column.

title: Add a log dose (in base 10) column to the input data.frame — calculate_log_dose
code: # Consider observations at doses of `1 μM` and `0.1 μM`. # If the doses are given in molar units e.g. `M` then, data <- data.frame(dose = c(1e-6, 1e-7)) %>%    BayesPharma::calculate_log_dose(dose_col = dose, molar_concentration = 1) #> Error in data.frame(dose = c(1e-06, 1e-07)) %>% BayesPharma::calculate_log_dose(dose_col = dose,     molar_concentration = 1): could not find function "%>%" data$log_dose == c(-6, -7) #> Error in data$log_dose: object of type 'closure' is not subsettable  # If the doses are given with in units of nanomolar units e.g. `nM` then data <- data.frame(dose_nM = c(1000, 100)) %>%   BayesPharma::calculate_log_dose(dose_col = dose_nM, molar_concentration = 1e-9) #> Error in data.frame(dose_nM = c(1000, 100)) %>% BayesPharma::calculate_log_dose(dose_col = dose_nM,     molar_concentration = 1e-09): could not find function "%>%" data$log_dose == c(-6, -7) #> Error in data$log_dose: object of type 'closure' is not subsettable

what: Change column names to be compatible with BayesPharma functions — change_col_names
title: Change column names to be compatible with BayesPharma functions — change_col_names
text: Given response, log_dose, predictors column data.frame,   change column names `response`, `log_dose`, `predictors` data.frame return .

title: Change column names to be compatible with BayesPharma functions — change_col_names
code: data <!-- %>% change_col_names( -->         response_col_name = <response_col_name>,         log_dose_col_name = <log_dose_col_name>,         predictors_col_name = <predictors_col_name>)

title: Change column names to be compatible with BayesPharma functions — change_col_names
text: response_col_name expression response column input data.frame (default = NULL). log_dose_col_name expression log_dose column input data.frame (default = NULL). log_dose calculated yet, calculate log_dose, use calculate_log_dose function. predictors_col_name expression predictors column input data.frame (default = NULL). Predictors perturbations tested experiment (.e. Drug, Temperature, etc.).

title: Change column names to be compatible with BayesPharma functions — change_col_names
text: input data.frame new column header names response column (`response`),   log_dose column (`log_dose`), predictors column (`predictors`).

title: Change column names to be compatible with BayesPharma functions — change_col_names
code: # consider the response column name is `normalized_measurement`, log dose column name is `log_10_dose`, # and predictors column name is `Drug`. data %>% BayesPharma::change_col_names(response_col_name = normalized_measurement,                                        log_dose_col_name = log_10_dose,                                        predictors_col_name = Drug) #> Error in data %>% BayesPharma::change_col_names(response_col_name = normalized_measurement,     log_dose_col_name = log_10_dose, predictors_col_name = Drug): could not find function "%>%"

what: Create a list of initial values of the model parameters — dr_inits
title: Create a list of initial values of the model parameters — dr_inits
text: Creating list lists containing initial values model parameters   used argument dr_model.

title: Create a list of initial values of the model parameters — dr_inits
code: dr_inits(       ec50 = -9,       hill = TRUE,       inhibitor = TRUE,       top = 100,       bottom = 0,       chains = 4)

title: Create a list of initial values of the model parameters — dr_inits
text: ec50 numeric units ec50 (default = -9). hill TRUE, FALSE, numeric units, TRUE/FALSE sets hill initial value 1/-1 numeric units can assigned hill (default = TRUE). inhibitor TRUE/FALSE value determines hill positive negative slope. TRUE, initial condition hill = -1. FALSE, hill = 1 (default = TRUE). top numeric units top (default = 100). bottom numeric units bottom (default = 0). chain numeric units Markov chains used brmsfit (default = 4).

title: Create a list of initial values of the model parameters — dr_inits
text: list lists.

what: Run Bayesian Regression Model using Stan — dr_model
title: Run Bayesian Regression Model using Stan — dr_model
text: additional information additional function arguments, reference: https://paul-buerkner.github.io/brms/reference/brm.html https://rdrr.io/cran/rstan/man/stan.html

title: Run Bayesian Regression Model using Stan — dr_model
code: dr_model(   data,   formula = dr_formula(),   priors = NULL,   inits = 0,   iter = 8000,   control = list(adapt_delta = 0.99),   ... )

title: Run Bayesian Regression Model using Stan — dr_model
text: data tibble data.frame experimental data. priors brmspriors data.frame ec50, hill, top, bottom. Use 'dr_priors' create priors use . inits list lists, numeric value, "random" initial values parameters modeled. (default = 0) iter number iterations model runs. Increasing iter can help model convergence. (default = 8000) control named list parameters control sampler's behavior. Adding max_treedepth giving greater value 10 can improve model convergence. (default = list(adapt_delta = 0.99)) multiple_perturbations TRUE/FALSE. FALSE, model produce singular estimate parameter. TRUE, parameter produce parameter estimates perturbation.

title: Run Bayesian Regression Model using Stan — dr_model
text: brmsfit

what: data.frame of pre-determined priors of parameters to be predicted by the model — dr_priors
title: data.frame of pre-determined priors of parameters to be predicted by the model — dr_priors
text: Creating data.frame priors dose response parameters    required model. function arguments ec50, hill, top, bottom = NULL, pre-set normal distribution priors set. inhibitor = TRUE, hill positive. inhibitor = FALSE, hill negative. like set parameter constant, enter numeric value function argument. like set distribution, example, function arguments type 'ec50 = brms::prior(distribution(mu,sigma), nlpar = 'ec50')'. distribution options, reference http://mc-stan.org/rstanarm/reference/priors.html#arguments.

title: data.frame of pre-determined priors of parameters to be predicted by the model — dr_priors
code: dr_priors(    ec50 = NULL,    hill = NULL,    inhibitor = TRUE,    top = NULL,    bottom = NULL)

title: data.frame of pre-determined priors of parameters to be predicted by the model — dr_priors
text: ec50 NULL, numeric units, brms::prior. NULL provide weakly informative prior. Setting ec50 numeric value set ec50 prior constant value given numeric value. prior choice can set using brms::prior(). (default = NULL) hill NULL, numeric value, brms::prior. NULL provide weakly informative prior. Setting hill numeric value set hill prior constant value given numeric value. prior choice can set using brms::prior(). (default = NULL) inhibitor TRUE/FALSE value. determines positive negative slope used hill prior. (default = TRUE) top NULL, numeric value, brms::prior. NULL provide weakly informative prior. Setting top numeric value set top prior constant value given numeric value. prior choice can set using brms::prior(). (default = NULL) bottom NULL, numeric value, brms::prior. NULL provide weakly informative prior. Setting bottom numeric value set bottom prior constant value given numeric value. prior choice can set using brms::prior(). (default = NULL)

title: data.frame of pre-determined priors of parameters to be predicted by the model — dr_priors
text: brmsprior data.frame

title: Create a plot of the predicted responses from the posterior distribution — plot_draws_data
text: model brmsfit. n number samples posterior distribution (default n = 100). lower number lowest log_dose value used calculating Response (default = -12). upper number highest log_dose value used calculating Response (default = -3). data tibble dataframe used brmsfit. predictors_col_name name column predictors used brmsfit. measurement column 'data' containing response values. draws tibble::tibble returned posterior_response_draws' function. pred_response 'Response' column tibble::tibble returned 'posterior_response_draws' function. mean_draws tibble::tibble returned 'posterior_mean' function. title string plot title. (default = NULL) xlabel string x-axis label. (default = NULL) ylabel string y-axis label. (default = NULL) predictors_name string. one perturbation tested, name predictor analyzed required avoid "NA" graph subtitle. (default = NULL)

title: Create a plot of the predicted responses from the posterior distribution — plot_draws_data
